title: 107_s691
content: The Washoe Tribe Land Conveyance is addressed in Section 1. Congress finds that the Washoe Tribe's ancestral homeland encompassed approximately 5,000 square miles around Lake Tahoe, California and Nevada. In 1997, the Washoe people were recognized as indigenous to the Lake Tahoe Basin through meetings convened by various government entities. In 1997, the Washoe people were recognized as indigenous to Lake Tahoe Basin through meetings held by government entities to protect the region's natural resources. This resulted in a multiagency agreement supporting the Tribe's traditional land uses, including access to National Forest System land. The multiagency agreement supports the Washoe Tribe's traditional land uses, including access to Lake Tahoe for cultural practices. The Act aims to return the Tribe to Lake Tahoe and ensure their access to the region. The Act aims to return the Washoe Tribe to Lake Tahoe for traditional cultural practices, including spiritual renewal, land stewardship, horticulture, subsistence gathering, and family reunification. The Act aims to ensure that members of the Washoe Tribe have the opportunity to engage in traditional cultural practices at Lake Tahoe for spiritual renewal, land stewardship, horticulture, subsistence gathering, traditional learning, and family reunification. The Secretary of Agriculture will convey land to the Secretary of the Interior, in trust for the Tribe, with certain conditions. The Secretary of Agriculture will convey approximately 24.3 acres of land to the Secretary of the Interior, in trust for the Washoe Tribe, for no cost. The land is located within the Lake Tahoe Basin Management Unit north of Skunk Harbor, Nevada. The Secretary of Agriculture will convey 24.3 acres of land to the Secretary of the Interior for the Washoe Tribe, with a reserved easement for public access over Forest Development Road #15N67. The Secretary of Agriculture will convey 24.3 acres of land to the Washoe Tribe with a reserved easement for public and administrative access over Forest Development Road #15N67. The Tribe will also receive a reciprocal easement for vehicular access for administrative and safety purposes. The Secretary of Agriculture will provide a reciprocal easement to the Washoe Tribe for vehicular access to a parcel over Forest Development Road #15N67. This access is for administrative and safety purposes, as well as for Tribe members who may have difficulty accessing the parcel on foot due to age, infirmity, or disability. The Tribe and its members must limit the use of the conveyed parcel to traditional and customary uses and stewardship. The Tribe and its members must limit the use of the conveyed parcel to traditional and customary uses and stewardship conservation. No permanent residential, recreational, or commercial development is allowed on the parcel. The conveyed parcel must be used for traditional and customary uses and conservation for the Tribe's benefit. No permanent residential, recreational, or commercial development is allowed, and environmental requirements must be met as per the Regional Plan of the Tahoe Regional Planning Agency. The conveyed parcel must be used for traditional and customary uses and conservation for the Tribe's benefit, with no permanent residential, recreational, or commercial development allowed. Environmental requirements must be met as per the Regional Plan of the Tahoe Regional Planning Agency. If the Tribe violates these conditions and fails to take corrective action directed by the Secretary of the Interior, the parcel may be terminated and reverted. If the Tribe violates land use conditions for the parcel and fails to take corrective action directed by the Secretary of the Interior, title to the parcel will revert to the Secretary of Agriculture. The Senate passed the document on August 1, 2002, with Jeri Thomson as the Secretary.
